events.summary: Bedřich Smetana was born, marking the entry of a future musical genius onto the stage of life, much to the relief of his parents who were quite busy after having ten children already. His arrival was likely celebrated with music, even if it was just his father fiddling around.

At the tender age of six, Smetana's miniature fingers danced over the piano keys for the first time in public, captivating the audience. Clearly, he didn't suffer from stage fright; he might have been practicing for this moment since birth!

In a burst of youthful idealism, Smetana decided to wear a revolutionary hat for a change and joined the barricades during the Prague uprising. He waved flags, wrote patriotic music, and probably thought he was composing the next hit single while dodging Austrian soldiers.

Smetana tied the knot with his beloved Kateřina Kolářová, proving that his heart was as passionate as his music. Four daughters followed, suggesting that balancing parenting and composing was a symphony of its own kind.

He became the principal conductor at Prague's Provisional Theatre, stepping into the spotlight only to find himself dodging controversies like a matador with musical talent. His experience was like conducting a circus where everyone else was juggling opinions!

Ironically, Smetana, already enveloped in his musical world, became completely deaf by the end of 1874. He approached this challenge heroically, apparently composing some of his most amazing works while literally tuning out all the noise around him.

Post-deafness, while others might wallow in silence, Smetana was busy composing at an astonishing pace, securing his status as a pivotal figure in Czech music. Who needs eardrums when you have creativity flowing through your veins?

A mental collapse led to an unfortunate stint in an asylum, marking a tragic yet ultimately human slice of life for this prolific composer. We can only imagine the soundtrack to his internal struggles; a somber symphony in the key of grief.

Bedřich Smetana passed away, leaving behind a legacy that would ensure he was forever remembered as the 'father of Czech music'. His music continues to bridge generations, providing a joyful echo of his ambition and talent long after his final curtain call.

Smetana created a piece to celebrate the wedding of Emperor Franz Joseph, which was rejected by the Imperial Court for not being 'Austrian' enough. He then went on to finance a performance himself, only to discover that getting noticed in Prague wasn't an easy task, especially when your own orchestra doesn't quite agree with your nationalistic flair.

events.event: Piano Trio in G minor performed
events.summary: After several personal losses, including his daughter's death, Smetana poured his feelings into a piano trio that critics described as 'harsh', although Liszt praised it. Apparently, not even the great composer could dodge a bad review these days!

Feeling unappreciated back home, Smetana decided it was time to search for greener pastures, stating 'Prague did not wish to acknowledge me, so I left it.' Talk about a dramatic exit! Off to Sweden he went, ready to show them what they were missing!

Smetana was surprised to find the music scene in Gothenburg rather 'unsophisticated'. Rather than complain, he opened a music school, only to be bombarded with students. Who knew he'd be a teacher before he became a celebrated composer?

After some time of soul-searching and heartbreak, Smetana fell in love with his sister-in-law, Barbora. They tied the knot and he thought, maybe I’ll inspire some music while we’re at it! They settled back into Sweden, where the couple began their own family.

Smetana finally got his big break with The Brandenburgers, premiering at the Provisional Theatre. The hype was unreal—he was called on stage nine times! Though, in later years, they might forget your birthdate; they never forget a repeat performance!

The initial performance of Smetana's most famous opera started on a hot night before the Austro-Prussian War, and it flopped worse than a pancake! However, it hit the sweet spot when restaged years later, capturing the audience's heart, and potentially their air-conditioning!

events.event: Became principal conductor of the Provisional Theatre
events.summary: With a turning tide in his career and some clever maneuvering, Smetana landed the role of principal conductor at the Provisional Theatre. There, he could serve up some standard works while sneakily slipping in his own, reminding everyone that he was still the star of the show!

Smetana helped kick off a cultural revolution by laying the foundation stone for the National Theatre. He even penned a Festive Overture for the occasion, proving that he could both dig and create music that plays in the background while you dig!

On the same night of the National Theatre's foundation, Smetana's third opera, Dalibor, premiered. Initially, the reception was warmer than a fresh loaf of bread, but the reviews were colder than the Czech winter, leading him to sigh with resignation.

After facing pressures and petitions to resign, Smetana was reappointed as conductor of the Provisional Theatre with a bigger salary. It was a classic 'they can't fire me, I quit!' scenario, but with more music and less drama.

Smetana completed his grand opera Libuše but decided to hold off on its premiere until the National Theatre opened. It's like baking a cake but waiting for the perfect occasion to serve it, only to find out the bakery caught fire!

Smetana's fifth opera, The Two Widows, premiered at the Provisional Theatre. Supported by his loyal fans, he received a decorative baton similar to those given to rebellious children who've just silenced their toys!

Smetana premiered the completed cycle of symphonic poems, Má vlast, showcasing his journey through Czech identity. It marked the composer getting intimately comfortable with his heritage, like a cozy blanket on a chilly day.

Finally, the grand premiere of Libuše at the National Theatre took place. Despite earlier ticket drama, the audience loved it and he basked in applause, feeling more like a celebrity than a conductor that night.

For his 60th birthday, a gala concert was organized but Smetana, much to everyone's chagrin, was too ill to attend. It was the thought that counted, much like sending a birthday card to someone who prefers cash!

In a determined bid to prove that he could pen something jolly about his homeland, Smetana created Má vlast, an exuberant cycle of symphonic poetry. Most assuredly, it would eventually leave audiences practically dancing through the streets—at least until they remembered they still had to pay their taxes!

events.event: First performance of The Bartered Bride
events.summary: Despite a little mishap with the opening night timing, The Bartered Bride waltzed its way into audience's hearts and became a staple in opera houses everywhere. Smetana might have quipped it was 'merely child's play,' but boy, did that child's play grow up to have quite the international impact!

After a tumultuous life, Smetana finally experienced the sweet triumph of a thunderous ovation for the complete performance of Má vlast, proving once and for all that his musical scribbles were more than just enthusiastic doodles.

In a last burst of creativity, Smetana whipped up Our Song, a cheerful piece despite a few hiccups with health. It sat around like an awkward relative for years before becoming an unexpected guest at the musical party in 1924!
